articleContentTranslated: Shortly after the start, the 34-year-old Grosjean crashed into the guardrail at a speed of around 220 km / h and an impact force of over 50 G after touching the Alpha Tauri of the Russian Daniil Kwjat.

His racing car was torn in two. The father of three, born in Geneva, was miraculously able to free himself from the wreck that went up in flames and was flown to the military hospital in Manama with burns on the back of both hands.

He also spent the night there, although the X-ray did not reveal any broken bones. A warm thank you to everyone Grosjean, with bandaged hands, sent greetings from the hospital bed that night and thanked everyone who had sent him messages.

â€œI just wanted to say I'm okay. Well, almost okay. I wasn't for the Halo a few years ago, but it's the greatest thing in F1, â€he said. It remains to be seen whether and when the Frenchman, who will no longer have a place at Haas in 2021, can return to his car.

Brawn was mainly concerned with the question of how the monocoque could dig itself into the guardrails and the car caught fire. â€œIt is shocking to see such a severe accident. We are no longer used to that, including fire, â€said the Englishman.

"The halo must have saved his life," Brawn was convinced. The ring-shaped and initially controversial head protection made of titanium over the driver's cell has been mandatory in Formula 1 since 2018. Halo (English) means translated halo.
"Things have happened that shouldn't have happened like this," Brawn said. â€œSince this accident at the latest, it has been clear that Halo is a life-saving part.

â€œShocking moments in Bahrain The first to be at the scene of the accident were Formula 1 doctor Ian Roberts and the driver of the medical car, Alan van der Merwe. "I haven't seen anything like it in twelve years," said Van der Merwe on TV.
â€œI have never witnessed such an impact. So it took us a few moments to understand what happened there.

It felt like an eternity. â€Fire accident overshadows the race A terrible fire accident dominates the Formula 1 race in Bahrain on Sunday: Accident driver Romain Grosjean probably got away with minor burns after a terrible crash.

Lewis Hamilton's win fades into the background. Van der Merwe was also convinced that the current safety standard in the top motorsport class had spared Grosjean from serious injuries or even saved his life.

Halo, guardrail and belts, everything apparently worked fine. â€œComparableâ€ to Lauda's accident Mercedes team boss Toto Wolff was thoughtful. â€œI don't even want to think about how this accident would have ended a few years ago,â€ said the Austrian.
